title: Is the global $19 trillion debt timebomb on the brink of blowing up?
text:
‘It’s like putting an obese patient on a high-carb diet but forcing him to take pills to suppress the side effects,” says Elwin de Groot, head of macro strategy at Rabobank.

The patient in question is the global economy and the diet of fry-ups and cheeseburgers represents the ultra-low interest rates that have led to a mountain of corporate debt.

“That what I would call the debt: a high-carb diet. That’s the easy monetary policy and we are trying to limit the consequences of that, or soften the edges, by giving the patient certain medicine,” adds De Groot, who fears debt problems are “building up under the surface” and the economy will find itself in “another crisis” before long.
